awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Structural differences between French and Picard: Evidence from phonetics and phonology
awd_abstract_narration:
When should a dialect be considered a different language? Though French and the Picard language both developed from Latin, the political and linguistic unification of France has led to a decline in the use of Picard. Today, Picard is classified as "severely endangered" by UNESCO, and considerable uncertainty has been expressed regarding its independence as a separate language. At worst, it is labeled a corrupted dialect of French, but recent linguistic analyses have revealed both important structural differences and complexities in Picard.

This project aims to expand that body of evidence with respect to nasality. Though the two languages share identical inventories of nasal and oral vowels, they are reported to display opposite patterns of regressive nasalization, i.e., where nasal airflow overlaps with a vowel before nasal consonants. Several phonetic studies have shown that this applies to high vowels /i, y, u/ in French, which have no nasal counterpart in either language. However, there is disagreement about whether this occurs at significant rates, and whether it is part of the phonological grammar of French or a minor phonetic reflex. Meanwhile, a major reference grammar of Picard reports that this process applies only to /a, e, o/, which do have nasal counterparts in both languages. However, in contrast with the French studies, there are no phonetic data for Picard to support these claims. Given the possibility that the French government might adopt policies that aim to increase its recognition and support for its regional languages and the general lack of empirical evidence concerning the languages that are most closely related to French, the proposed research is both urgent and extremely timely.

Nasal acoustic energy will be measured to document which vowels undergo nasalization, and to what extent, in Picard, Standard French, and the regional French of Picardie. This project will offer not only a phonological analysis of an understudied language, but also a comparative analysis of two closely related languages. In addition, this study may reveal insights concerning structural relations among nasal vowels. By determining major phonological differences from low-level phonetic phenomena, this study will contribute objective criteria by which a full-fledged language may be distinguished from a dialect, and its methodology is easily adapted to any setting where similar work is needed.

por.por_cntn:
When vowels come into contact with nasal consonants, languages may differ significantly in terms of nasal assimilation, that is, how nasal those vowels are allowed to become. For instance, vowels are typically 100% nasal in these contexts in English, while on average French shows much lower rates (depending on the identity of the vowel). Such phonetic data provide insight into deeper differences belonging to the domain of phonology, the part of a language's grammar which traditionally organizes sounds. 


This project documented first of all phonetic differences between European French and Picard, a severely endangered language spoken in Northern France and Belgium. It examined the rates of nasality on vowels both in the absence and presence of nasal consonants. This was achieved with the use of a nasometer, an instrument which records oral and nasal channels separately. This study translated these data into a comparative phonological analysis. This was achieved by classifying vowels which were 50% nasal or more as nasal in the grammar; therefore, vowels meeting this criterion next to nasal consonants were considered actively targeted for nasalization as a phonological process. All in all, this study found significant divergences between French and Picard which could not be explained in terms of superficial differences of pronunciation.


In terms of sheer rates of nasality, in non-nasal contexts, French and Picard displayed essentially identical "building blocks" at either extreme -- that is, certain vowels which are 0% and near-100% nasal. Meanwhile, before nasal consonants, both languages showed high levels of nasality on the vowels /i/ (as in English "see") and /y/ (its equivalent with lip rounding). However, only in Picard did vowels /a, e, o/ meet the half-nasal criterion before nasal consonants; these vowels showed negligible nasality in French in this context.


It is of no small consequence that in both languages, in the lack of nasal consonants, only these three vowel qualities stand in contrast with completely nasal counterparts. In other words, the difference between /a, e, o/ and their respective nasal counterparts may be used in distinguishing meaning in both languages (but not so for /i/, for example). Therefore, in terms of nasalization, Picard levels its oral-nasal distinction, while French preserves it. 


The phonological analysis demonstrated formally that such a difference cannot stem from the same grammar. The patterns in each language corresponded to different, though equally legitimate responses to universal pressures; that is, neither language should be considered "purer" than the other. Namely, while French preserves its oral-nasal distinction, it does so at the cost of introducing typologically undesirable sequences of oral vowel + nasal consonant.


The evidence for independent grammars between French and Picard was just one of several other outcomes of this project. First, this project serves as (to my knowledge) the first phonetic study, instrumental or not, of Picard. Second, this study pioneered the use of a new calculation of vowel nasality, called the Differential Energy Ratio (DER). This method is currently being promoted as inherently more accurate than previous, commonplace calculations. Finally, the data collected in this project and their accompanying phonological analysis serve as the basis for a formal theory of the abstract representation of and relationship among nasal vowels, which is currently lacking in the literature.


The rich database collected during this project will also provide the basis for several other projects to come.
